awd_titl_txt: CRII: CHS: Adaptive Virtual Environments for a Prolonged Exposure Therapy of Attention Deficits on Autism Spectrum
awd_abstract_narration:
The goal of this research is to develop and evaluate an adaptive virtual reality (VR) system that will enable an innovative therapy for children with attention deficit on the autism spectrum. The prevalence of autism spectrum disorder (ASD) in the United State has grown significantly in recent years, and while there have been some successful efforts to address this issue by exploiting VR-based therapies, most of them merely use VR as an alternative way to simulate existing approaches. An important feature of VR technology - the ability to generate "impossible experiences" (i.e., experiences that cannot be created in the real world, such as a chair disappearing upon the user's gaze) - seems to be missing in these systems, because this feature was not available when most traditional ASD therapies were developed. The envisaged system will employ specifically designed "impossible experiences" to deliver an individualized therapy that addresses the attention deficits of children with ASD. The research will improve the learning ability for children with ASD and provide novel design guidelines for future VR systems used in ASD therapy. 

The PI will study research questions and develop the system incrementally. The overall logic of the system is: 1) Expose the user to a virtual environment to finish a task (e.g., listen to a virtual teacher talking); 2) Detect the user's attention with eye-tracking data and physiological signals, then remove all the detected distractions (e.g., a red mug) from the virtual environment; 3) Gradually restore all distractions into the virtual environment, expose the user to one more distraction object at a time and reinforce the correct attention. To implement this strategy, the PI will first explore attention capture in VR and strategies for reinforcement in VR through short user studies. Then, the effectiveness of the entire system will be evaluated through a six-month long, multiple-baseline design across participants study. All the studies will be conducted with K-12 students with medium to high levels of ASD.

This award reflects NSF's statutory mission and has been deemed worthy of support through evaluation using the Foundation's intellectual merit and broader impacts review criteria.

por.por_cntn:
Throughout the funding period, the research team embarked on a comprehensive endeavor to develop and assess a wearable hardware and software system aimed at enhancing sustained attention among students, particularly those diagnosed with Autism Spectrum Disorder (ASD). The research initiative aimed to create an adaptive virtual environments therapy (AVET) system utilizing virtual reality (VR), which would offer groundbreaking therapeutic interventions for children on the autism spectrum with attention deficits. Through extensive research and development efforts, a prototype of the AVET system was successfully engineered, harnessing interactive VR and employing dynamic feedback techniques to foster sustained attention. Notably, the dynamic feedback employed in the VR scenarios includes four distinct strategies incorporating both positive and negative reinforcement: score, noise, red vignette, and opacity. To assess the efficacy of the system, a meticulously designed effectiveness study was conducted, encompassing participants with ASD as well as those without. Physiological data was collected using the E4 wristband wearable device, and eye-tracking sensors embedded in the HTC Vive Eye Pro headset were utilized to analyze various eye metrics and identify sources of distraction. Furthermore, the study involved comparative analyses of the different intervention strategies employed to determine their impact on attention levels.

The research outcomes have provided valuable insights into the effectiveness of the attention training system based on virtual reality (VR) and have made significant contributions to the knowledge base regarding attention intervention utilizing immersive technology. In collaboration with a local special education academy, experiments were conducted involving both students with Autism Spectrum Disorder (ASD) and those without, employing state-of-the-art wearable technologies to capture physiological data and ocular behavior. Through comprehensive analysis of the collected data, which encompassed a wide range of statistical, temporal, and morphological features, notable improvements in attention levels were observed among participants who engaged with the VR-based system. These findings not only enhance the understanding of attention enhancement techniques but also open up possibilities for further advancements in the field. Importantly, this innovative approach holds promise not only for students with ASD but also for enhancing attention and learning in various educational settings.

The project has also contributed to the professional development of graduate and undergraduate students involved in the research process. Through the awarded grant, the PI provided training and mentorship to three graduate students and four undergraduate students, equipping them with valuable skills in the areas of VR technology, data analysis, and research methodology. The dissemination of the findings to scientific communities, through publications and conference presentations, has already generated interest and sparked collaborations, contributing to the advancement of knowledge and theory in attention research and educational technology.

In conclusion, the project has made significant strides in enhancing attention and learning through the use of VR technology. The outcomes and findings of the research contribute to the intellectual merit of the field and hold broader impacts for education, human resources, technology transfer, and society at large. The awarded project has established a strong foundation for future advancements in attention enhancement and educational practices.
